It is hard for customers to gauge things like reliability , so it tends not to be the prime factor in making a buying decision . PC makers want to keep warranty returns within an acceptable range without incurring a lot of extra engineering and manufacturing expense . And they want to emphasize the things that will get consumers to buy their machine . So as a result , they spend just enough on engineering to make it likely that the PC will last long enough . It \'s a business decision . This also has historically worked out for the industry because the ever increasing processing power of microelectronics has meant that after a few years , a PC is considered " old " and " slow " . Microsoft has helped this by continually bloating Windows with patches to help slow machines down over time . So consumers have gotten used to the idea that they " need " to buy a new computer every few years .', 'Who says they last 4 - 5 years ? Video card , motherboard / cpu etc etc ... This way the gradual upgrades do n\'t cost as much as a brand new box out the pocket . I currently use a Core i7 920 which i got in 2009 overclocked to 4ghz , 12 gb of ram and , with a GTX 680x2 in SLI it runs pretty much every single game at maxed out settings on my 30 " panel . Initial investment in 2009 was about $ 1200 ( built it myself , and that does n\'t account for the monitor ) and then i just swapped out video cards over the years . Also depends on what you buy . If you get a high end Dell like Alienware or XPS they should be upgradable for some time , if you buy a MAC however ( which by hardware terms is already out of date brand new ) upgrading is pretty much a moot point']
chatgpt_answers: ["Computers are made up of many different components, and each of those components has a limited lifespan. Because of these limitations, computers typically don't last forever. For example, a desktop computer that is used infrequently and has a high-quality power supply may last longer than a laptop that is used heavily and has a lower-quality power supply."]

question: What is the difference between sex and gender ? What is the difference between sex and gender ? What is the difference between transgender , transsexual , and transvestite ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['Sex is a biological attribute . Gender is an identity attribute . A person with can be biologically male ( sex ) , but they can identify as female ( gender ) . The doctor looks at the genitalia and writes " male " or " female " on the birth certificate . Usually it \'s a clear distinction , but there are people who are born intersex whose genitalia are not male or female , and it \'s up to the doctor \'s judgment to pick one . We learn in biology class that male is XY and female is XX , but there are also genetic abnormalities where someone can be X ( Turner syndrome ) or XXY ( Kleinfelter syndrome ) , so even that distinction is blurry . Of course , in 99 % of cases , sex is easy to determine , but I feel like this is worth mentioning . It \'s difficult to come up with an objective definition of sex , basically . Gender is how a person feels and/or chooses to represent themselves to the outside world . In the vast majority of cases , gender and sex are the same thing , which is why historically the terms have been used entirely interchangeably . Someone who feels that they are a woman but was assigned " male " at birth is transgendered , as is a person who was assigned female at birth but feels that they are a man . Transsexual is used somewhat interchangeably , but it \'s sometimes used to describe someone who has undergone surgery to alter their genitalia whereas " transgender " does not necessarily mean that they \'ve had surgery . A transvestite is someone who identifies as one gender but dresses like the opposite gender , like a drag queen . Someone who is transgender is not a transvestite , they \'re very different things . " edit : I should also mention that if you accidentally refer to a transgender person as a " transvestite , " they \'ll be really offended . " Transvestite " says " you are a man that likes to dress up as a girl , " so it will really piss someone off if they feel that they genuinely are a girl . second edit : I should add that textbooks generally define sex in terms of which role an individual plays in reproduction . In mammals and reptiles , for example , the female receives genetic material from the male and gives birth to offspring ( either as an egg or as live young ) . The problem with defining it that way is that it does n\'t really leave room to define the sex of individuals that are sterile at birth , nor does it clearly define any sort of * permanence * since there are a number of hermaphroditic species .', '[ This is a good infographic ] ( URL_0 )']

question: What happens to a cucumber or other food when it 's pickled ? How exactly does the vinegar solution pickles are in saturate and preserve them ? What changes about the cucumber 's chemistry that changes the taste and keeps it from spoiling ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['Pickling is a fermentation process involving lactobacillus bacteria that can tolerate a high salinity environment which kills almost all other micro - organisms . The lactobacilli break down the structure of the cucumber changing its structure and also produce different compounds which change the flavor and increase the acidity of the cucumbers . Additionally , osmosis infuses the pickle with flavors from spices added to the pickling liquid . You end up with a salty , acidic , spice infused pickle that is not only preserved against rot from the action of other micro - organisms but a much different flavor', "Fermentation with natural bacteria is the traditional method of pickling . The bacteria are anaerobic , so the do not use oxygen . The veg to be pickled is submerged in salt water to keep out oxygen and inhibit growth of dangerous bacteria . Lactobacillus is the main bacteria that ferment pickled veg . These guys are everywhere all the time . They are rod shaped and use the lactic acid fermentation pathway . This makes an acidic solution that gives the characteristic sour taste to the salt brine . Incidentally , garlic cloves turn blue during pickling . This was alarming the first time , but Google assured me it was normal and safe , and the garlic was delicious ! For your first go , use 2 - 5 % salt solutions ( 20 - 50 g salt per liter water ) , sprigs of fresh dill , whole garlic cloves ( peeled ) , and cucumber spears . Alum supposedly keeps the pickles crisp ; that 's my next project as my last pickles were slimy and inedible . I also recommend something like [ this ] ( URL_0 ) to vent the carbon dioxide has without letting oxygen into your pickles . Oxygen would allow dangerous bacteria to grow . Good luck !", 'URL_1 URL_0 I think this is appropriate for this sub .']
chatgpt_answers: ["\\nWhen you pickle a cucumber or other food, you put it in a jar with vinegar and sometimes other ingredients like salt, sugar, and spices. The vinegar solution pickles the cucumber by soaking into it and changing its chemistry.\\n\\nThe vinegar contains acetic acid, which can preserve the cucumber by killing off any bacteria or other microorganisms that might cause it to spoil. The acid in the vinegar also changes the cucumber's cell structure, making it more firm and crunchy.\\n\\nThe salt and sugar in the vinegar solution can also help preserve the cucumber by drawing water out of it and making it harder for bacteria to grow. The spices in the solution can give the pickled cucumber a different flavor than it had before.\\n\\nOverall, pickling a cucumber changes its taste and texture, and helps it last longer without going bad."]

question: How X - rays are produced ? Studying A level physics , wondering if anyone can give me a clear explanation . Thank you . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['There is more than one way , but I believe in standard x - ray machines , you start with an electron gun ( a heated cathode ) , then you accelerate the electrons and shoot them into matter so that they emit bremsstrahlung radiation in the x - ray part of the EM spectrum .', "Its actually rather simple . There are 2 main components . A Cathode ( - ) and an Anode ( + ) . There is a filament in the Cathode , that heats up ( much like the filament in a toaster ) and burns off electrons . Those electrons , which are negatively charged are attracted to the positive Anode , most commonly made of Tungsten . When those electrons hit the Tungsten plate , boom , X - Rays . For a more somewhat in - depth look at the design of today 's modern X - Ray Tubes , check out [ this site ] ( URL_0 ) .", 'The standard procedure is to accellerate electrons from a heated filament onto a target . The fast electrons interact with the electrons in your target and raise their energy level . After a short time the exited electrons " fall back " onto their inital energy state and by that they emit electro - magnetic radiation . The material of your target determines the energy ( wavelength ) of the produced radiation , for creating X - rays cooper is often used .']
chatgpt_answers:
['X-rays are a type of electromagnetic radiation, similar to light or radio waves. They have a shorter wavelength and higher frequency than visible light and are not visible to the human eye. 
To produce X-rays, a machine called an X-ray generator is used. The generator has an electron gun, which is a device that produces a stream of high-energy electrons. These electrons are accelerated through a tube inside the generator and are then directed towards a metal target, usually made of tungsten. 
As the high-energy electrons collide with the metal target, they release energy in the form of X-rays. This process is called bremsstrahlung, which means "braking radiation" in German. The X-rays produced by the generator are then directed towards the part of the body being examined, and they pass through the body and are captured on film or a digital detector on the other side. 
X-rays are used in many medical and industrial applications because they can pass through most materials and produce images of the inside of objects. They are particularly useful for examining bones, as they are absorbed by soft tissue but not by bone. This allows doctors to see the inside of the body and identify any problems or injuries.']

question: What exactly does shifting my car into D3 do ? In my automatic car , what exactly is D3 ? How is it different from D ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["It 's for driving in the mountains . D will allow your car to go into the highest gear ... your car may not have enough power to maintain a consistent speed in this gear , so it will drop into a lower gear to get back up to speed . This cycle can be annoying . D3 prevents you from going to the highest gear . Additionally , when going down a hill , shifting into D3 will use a lower gear for more effective engine breaking .", "Everyone 's explanation , except for the guy at the bottom , has given a correct explanation . From your questions , maybe an analogy will help . For example , a ten speed bike . The gears by the pedals is the transmission , and the gears at the rear tire is the differential . In cars , the gears in the differential do n't change . Just like a ten - speed , when you hit the last gear , you are traveling very fast , but pedaling slowly . When you hit a hill , you must go down in gear in order to maintain speed , but this increases how much you have to pedal . In a car , placing the shifter in D3 is forcing the transmission to remain at that gear and not shifting up . Higher gears in automatic transmissions are only meant to maintain vehicle speed with as little power as possible . Not suitable for hills or mountainous terrain .", 'As has been explained , it means 3rd gear . On your vehicle , 4th gear is an overdrive gear , meaning it has a final drive that is less than a 1:1 ratio for better gas mileage . Now , the * reason * your shifter is probably marked 1 - 2 - D3 - OD is that D3 is used when you are driving in hills to keep the transmission from " hunting " between 3rd and 4th . But , it is considered a final drive gear , hence the reason it is distinguished with the " D " as oppsed to 1st and 2nd which are rarely used in an automatic ... meaning the driver rarely shifts down to those gears . Most of the time it \'s best to just keep it in OD and let the computer take care of shifting .']

question: Why is a computer keyboard set up the way it is ? Edit : Was their a person that invented the layout ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["QWERTY was initially developed to help keep typewriters from jamming . Early models would jam if two keys were hit too quickly in succession . So people got used to it . Once the jamming problem was solved , you were still left with all the typists who learned QWERTY . So if you 're a firm hiring typists you would severely limit your pool of candidates if you were to switch to a quicker system like DVORAK , since nearly everyone only knows the original . This huge disincentive to change has carried over to today .", 'Short answer : Because it is horribly outdated . Long answer : Back when the typewriter came out , typing too quickly on the device caused the keys to jam . So there had to be a medium of typing quickly , but not so fast that you jam your machine . Thus , QWERTY was born . It is totally designed to slow you down while typing to avoid jamming your typewriter . Also being able to type the word typewriter using only the top row of keys was probably a selling point , too . There are other , vastly improved keyboard layouts , but ultimately they are not used because the QWERTY style is what people grew up with , and they are too stubborn to make the switch that should have happened when computers first came around . You can look into other keyboard layouts , and even use them yourself by visiting the links below . URL_0 URL_1', '[ This article ] ( URL_0 ) does a decent job explaining the main reason ( as far as I know ) . The first typewriter used a mechanism that swung when the letter was hit . The machine , being a new invention , was a bit slow and clunky . If two letters were hit in quick succession , the keys would clash ( their swinging bars ) and the machine would ( in essence ) freeze . The inventor took common letter pairs , such as T and H and made sure they were at a safe distance from one another as to avoid failure on the part of the machine .']
chatgpt_answers: ['The layout of a computer keyboard is based on the layout of a traditional typewriter keyboard. The first successful mechanical typewriter was developed by Christopher Latham Sholes in the 1870s, and the layout of the keys was designed to reduce the risk of jamming the keys as they were struck by the hammers. The keys are arranged in a QWERTY layout, which is named after the first six letters on the top row of the keyboard. The QWERTY layout was designed to slow down typists so that the mechanical arms on the typewriter would not jam.\r\n\r\nIn the early days of computers, keyboards were designed to mimic the layout of typewriters, and so the QWERTY layout became the standard for computer keyboards as well. Today, the QWERTY layout is used on most computer keyboards around the world, although there are some variations in the layout of certain keys depending on the country or language.']

question: What is a computer ' memory leak ' ? I see it 's a huge issue with PC software but have no clue what it means . Can someone kindly explain it to me in simple terms please Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['Modern operating systems let you run multiple programs at once , but you only have one pool of RAM that they all have to share . The way that works is that when a program wants memory , it asks the operating system for however much it needs , and the OS finds a block that \'s not being used and loans it to the program . When the program is done using the memory , it \'s supposed to return it so other programs can use it . A memory leak happens when a program forgets about a block of memory the operating system gave it . As far as the operating system is concerned , it still has that block " checked out " , but the program ca n\'t do anything with it , and it ca n\'t return it back to the operating system because it ca n\'t find it . The memory is n\'t gone permanently- when the program exits , the operating system knows it does n\'t need the memory any more so it marks all the memory that was checked out by the program as " available " again . But it \'s not going to be available as long as that program is still running . It \'s only a big problem if the program keeps doing this . If it keeps hitting the code where it asks for more memory , but never returns any of it . Since it \'s not giving any memory back , the program will , over time , consume more and more of your computer \'s memory until you do n\'t have any more memory to give it . At that point , the computer has three choices : 1 . It can start rejecting requests from programs that ask for more memory ( which generally results in those programs crashing ) 2 . It can try storing additional data on the hard drive , which keeps the computer running but is something like 1000x slower than RAM so your computer will slow to a crawl 3 . It can try to figure out which program is stealing all of the memory and terminate that one ( Linux does this , Mac and Windows do n\'t since some programs do n\'t deal well with not having time to clean up ) EDIT : formatting', "Software developer here , Memory is a finite resource , your computer has only so much of it . Every program needs memory , and it 's use has to be coordinated to ensure no two programs overwrite each other . That coordination typically happens through the OS as the mediator between all other programs and memory . Every program keeps track of what memory addresses it 's using . Typically , when a program needs memory , it will request what it needs , and when it 's done with that memory , it will release it back into the pool of available memory . Most programs , it 's the responsibility of the programmer to allocate and free the memory . Oversights are common , and an algorithm may allocate memory without releasing it when finished . The OS does n't know the program is done with that memory , it does n't know there 's an error that is allocating without releasing memory , and the program error may be such that the program loses track of which bytes it no longer needs , and now it ca n't release it back to the OS . This is a memory leak . The pool of memory is slowly draining . This can bog down your system until the offending process is killed and the allocated memory can be reclaimed , if other processes do n't themselves start failing .", 'I think the best ELI5 would be to equate a computer as a teacher , and computer programs as little students . So ... a little kid asks for a marker from the teacher . Teacher hands it out . When the student is finished with the marker , they return it to the teacher - and the teacher puts it back into the marker jar . Now what ends up happening , is that there \'s * a lot * of little kids asking for markers . At once . Teacher dutifully hands them out . Now , little kids being little kids , some * forget * that they already have a marker and ask for another one . They inadvertently keep the first marker , while using the second marker . Sometimes they forget they have two , and then ask for a third . So when the teacher runs out of markers , she freaks the fuck out . Yells at all of the kids , kicks them out of the room , scours the whole room for markers , and puts them back . Now imagine each " marker " being a piece of memory . A memory leak occurs when the little shits ( programs ) forget that they have markers yet keep asking for more , and the teacher knows that they exist somewhere but not sure * exactly * where . You reclaim memory ( markers ) when you refresh everything and start over .']
chatgpt_answers: ["Sure! A memory leak is a problem that can occur in a computer program when it fails to release memory that it no longer needs. Imagine you have a bucket that you fill up with water. Every time you use the bucket, you empty it out and put it back where it belongs.\\n\\nNow imagine that instead of emptying the bucket and putting it back, you just keep filling it up without ever getting rid of the old water. Eventually, the bucket will overflow and make a big mess. That's kind of like what happens with a memory leak.\\n\\nA memory leak can cause a computer program to use more and more memory over time, until it becomes full and the program can't function properly. It's like the bucket getting bigger and bigger, but still never having room for all the water.\\n\\nMemory leaks are often caused by bugs in the code of a program, and they can be difficult to fix. But it's important to try to fix them, because they can make a computer slow down and crash."]

question: What is DirectX and why do you need it ? I never really understood it in the first place . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['These explanations are all brutal if you \'re supposed to be actually explaining DX to laymen . I will put everything in point form because I \'m a software engineer and do n\'t believe in wasting my time with stupid crap like grammar , haha . - DirectX is a piece of software ( called an API ) developed by Microsoft for their Windows Operating System - It allows programs on your computer , such as video games , CAD software , etc to access your computer \'s hardware ( such as graphics , sound , keyboard and mouse ) in a very lightweight manner - Very importantly , it allows hardware independence . This means that the same video game will work on every computer without having to be rewritten for every single machine it \'s expected to run on - It is actually composed of a couple of components : Direct3D , DirectShow , DirectSound , DirectInput , and a few more I \'m probably missing . - By far , the most important of these ( and the one MS has sunk the most time and money into ) is Direct3D. - As you may know , everything you see in a 3D video game is made of a bunch of polygons . Even if you see a sphere , it \'s actually made of a bunch of tiny triangles that are so small that they give the illusion of a smooth curve . - Here is an example of Leon from Resident Evil 4 to help you visualize this fact : URL_0 - Direct3D allows video games to say to the 3D graphics hardware , " Hey man , here are a bunch of triangles and here are instructions on where to put them , what color they should be , what textures they should have , how to light them up , etc " - DirectSound allows video games to say to the sound card , " Hey dude , here is a sound wave I want to you play through the speakers at this volume , with this speed , and I want you to mix it with several other sounds " - A version of DirectX has shipped with Windows ever since Windows 95 , but they were horrible . - Windows XP shipped with DirectX 9 , which was considered to be the first version of DX that did n\'t totally suck . - Ever since then , DirectX 10 came with Vista and DirectX 11 with Windows 7 . - Video games are generally tested with very specific subversions of DirectX , Ex . DirectX Version 10.2.2345 - Since they do n\'t want to take a risk with a version they were n\'t tested on , they almost always install DirectX on your computer whether they need it or not . - Luckily , Microsoft was smart enough to come up with a versioning system that makes it so they do n\'t all step on each other \'s feet .', 'DirectX is a set of programming libraries which interact with the drivers for the hardware on your computer . The idea is that when writing an application , a developer can use DirectX algorithms instead of having to reinvent them to save time and effort .', "DirectX is a collection of multimedia APIs for programmers . Mostly for gaming but also a / v players and editors . They abstract the really grimy details of how to interact with the hardware on a system so a developer does n't need to add code to their programs to deal with different ways of accomplishing something or different capabilities of various pieces of hardware like video or sound cards . You need DirectX installed because when a developer uses DirectX in their program , their program just contains a reference to code in the DirectX library and not the actual code . So you just install it once on your system and then everything that needs it knows where to find it ."]

Imagine that you want to play a video game on your computer. You would need a way to get the game's images and sounds from the game's software onto your screen and speakers. DirectX helps make this happen by providing a set of standard rules and tools that game developers can use to make their games work smoothly on your computer.

So, you need DirectX because it helps make sure that games and other programs run smoothly and look great on your computer."]

question: How AI technology works in first / third person shooter videogames ? How do AI characters react to your moves in shooter videogames ? Also how do difficulty levels work for AI ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['Valve has published a [ slide deck ( PDF ) ] ( URL_0 ) on how they designed the AI for Left 4 Dead . It \'s a bit more on the technical side if that \'s what you \'re interested in . Difficulty levels are just based on how fast the AI reacts and how much error you allow it to have . It \'s really easy to make the " perfect " AI because the computer always knows exactly where you are . So to make the game playable , you have to make the AI more stupid- it has to have some random error in its shots and you have to simulate some form of " vision " and reaction time or else the bad guys will just snipe you with a hitscan weapon from across the map as soon as the game starts . For a more difficult game , you just turn down the stupid factor .', "Disclaimer : not an A.I. programmer , but this is my understanding of how you can go about it . There may be better ways to script an A.I. Typically you are programming a series of ' If this Then that ' statements . There can be levels of complexity in how this is done , but it can be generalized somewhat to ' If- > Then ' . For example , lets assume that we have a PlayerChar object that can return its location . We can check if it is in range , aim at it , and fire at that location IF ( isInRange(PlayerChar.location ) ) THEN { aimAt(PlayerChar.location ) ; fireAt(PlayerChar.location ) ; } would check if the Player 's Character is within the AI characters ' range ' , ' aim ' at that location , and ' fire ' at that location . You might also program the A.I. to look for cover . Lets assume we have an array that stores nearby objects that are ' cover ' , and can choose randomly from that array to decide where to hide before moving to that location IF ( isInRange(PlayerChar.location ) ) THEN { coverArray = searchForCover(me.location ) ; cover = pickRandom(coverArray ) ; moveToLocation(cover.location ) ; IF ( isInRange(PlayerChar.location ) ) THEN { aimAt(PlayerChar.location ) ; fireAt(PlayerChar.location ) ; } } Using logical steps in that manner , we could program a very basic enemy A.I. that checks for an enemy in range , looks for cover , moves to cover , and begins to aim and fire at the player . Depending on the complexity of the A.I. these logical steps can get very , very complicated , and have a lot of checks and special logic , e.g A.I. can only detect in a particular cone of view , they can detect sound , vision , they can react to alarms and move to that location , so on and so forth . With difficulty levels , what you might adjust is how well the A.I. reacts . Maybe they have better range , a wider cone of vision , maybe they pick better cover , or are more ' intelligent ' with how they react to your presence . For example , at a lower difficulty , I might allow the A.I. to have more of a delay before searching for cover . But at a higher difficulty , not only will they always run for cover , but they will coordinate with nearby A.I. to lay down alternating fire to keep your character suppressed . With programming an A.I , you usually already have the code for how the ' player ' character works . You now are designing code to do all the things a ' player ' character can do , but automatically based on known inputs ( e.g. the player moves into range , an alarm goes off , an event script tells the A.I. where to go , etc . )", "There is really no single answer to this question : shooter video games are not all exactly alike , and even small changes in the game ( available weapon choices , player abilities , common features and motifs in maps ) could require somewhat different behavior from the AI in order to make sense . For example , a shooter with many splash damage weapons would require effective AI to actively try to avoid standing too close to other AI bots , while this would not be a factor in shooters that mostly involve high accuracy , slow firing weapons . Now , this is a gross simplification ( especially since I have limited knowledge of Artificial Intelligence techniques and no knowledge of game - oriented AI ) but a reasonable model for the AI could be a classical State - based representation of the world . State - based representation means that at any given point in time , the algorithm ruling the bot will consider all sorts of various factors ( distance from player , line of sight , player 's equipped weapon , map topography etc ) and use some pre - defined function in order to evaluate the Value of that state ( the higher the value , the more likely the bot will want to be in that state ) . The bot will then evaluate some ( or all ) of its available moves , create many estimates for the possible states that will be created as a result ( and estimate the probability of each hypothetical state ) , and then use another computation ( such as the average state value , or the maximal minimum if the AI wants to minimize risk to itself ) in order to finally select what move to perform . This action is repeated between every two moves the bot performs . It 's not always a very hard computation -- mostly it depends on how many moves deep the algorithm will consider . Having such a system in place , it is possible to tweak the AI 's difficulty level by introducing errors , limiting the amount of moves considered , limiting options at specific instances or even explicitly forcing the algorithm to make sub - optimal choices , say , 5 % of the time . Naturally many , many other types of AIs exist . What I covered is really just a tip of the iceberg ."]
chatgpt_answers:
['In a first/third person shooter video game, the AI characters are computer-controlled characters that move and act in the game. They are programmed to react to your moves and try to defeat you, just like a human player would.

The way the AI characters react to your moves depends on the game and how it was programmed. Some games have very basic AI characters that only do a few specific things, while others have more advanced AI characters that can adapt and change their behavior based on what you do.

The difficulty level of the game changes how hard it is to defeat the AI characters. If the difficulty is set to "easy," the AI characters might not be very good at shooting and might make mistakes. If the difficulty is set to "hard," the AI characters might be very skilled and make fewer mistakes.']

question: How do computers work on the * most * basic level Emphasis on most . Not programming but at the physical level . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["1 = on 0 = off each refers to the state of an electronic switch called a transistor . these are arranged as ' logic gates ' gates with names such as AND , OR , NOT URL_0 These are set out in paths which the signls go down eventually leading to an output connect lots of these togeher in the right order and you get a basic circuit based computer like Pong or a Calculator . In a more complex system the paths of the electronic signals can be programmed and you get more complex results such as Grand Theft Auto .", 'Electricity flows . By turning switches on and off it can be made to flow to different places . Those places do stuff when they get electricity . Maybe make a noise or make a pixel turn on or off . Put together millions of switches and you can do some complex things . Programming basically tells the electricity where to go and when it gets there , stuff happens .', 'From a circuitry perspective , here \'s what s happening : Imagine you have switches , which you can turn on and off . ( You typically see on represented as a " 1 " and off represented as a " 0 " - this is known as the binary representation , where the prefix " bi " means two , since a switch can only be on or off ) . You , as the user , set the value of these switches . That is , you turn them on and off in different orders to represent different inputs ( You can use the order of on vs off switches to represent numbers . For instance , 101 represents 5 . For more , you can view a simple explanation of binary number representation [ here ] ( URL_5 ) . ) Each of these switches you have has a wire , and this wire connects your switches to " logic gates " . Simple logic gates take in typically one or two inputs and make a decision ( output ) based on those inputs . The 3 most basic logic gates are " and " , " or " , and " not " . The " and " gate produces an " on " message if /both/ of its inputs are on . The " or " gate produces an " on " message if /either/ of its inputs are on . The " not " gate takes in only one input , and produces an " on " message if its input is off , and vice versa . Here are visualizations of those gates in action , where bright green is " on " and dark green is " off " . The And gate , where one input is on and the other is off , produces an " off " message : [ X ] ( URL_9 ) The And gate , where both inputs are on , produces an " on " message : [ X ] ( URL_3 ) The Or gate , where either input is on , produces an " on " message : [ X ] ( URL_4 ) [ X ] ( URL_2 ) When both inputs are on , the Or gate still produces an " on " message : [ X ] ( URL_6 ) The " not " gate flips the message it receives : [ X ] ( URL_1 ) [ X ] ( URL_7 ) If you want to download this program to play around with gates and learn more , its called [ Logisim ] ( URL_8 ) and is totally free ! Long story short , you can combine many of these inputs and gates to do increasingly complex things . For instance , here is an example of a [ full adder ] ( URL_0 ) in Logisim whose job is to add two single inputs ( 1 or 0 ) and determine their sum . From the full adder you can build a 4 - bit adder ( which can add two numbers as big as 15 ) , etc . The possibilities are huge !']

question: American Football I am British , and occasionally watch an NFL game . I enjoy it , but I have no idea what the hell is happening . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['The game starts with a kickoff . The team that catches the ball is now on offense , the kicking team is defense . The offense will now attempt to get the ball to the opposing goal line to score . The can use running plays , or passing plays . They have 4 tries ( called downs ) to move the ball forward 10 yards for a " 1st Down " . If they achieve this feat , they will start again with 4 more downs and another 10 yard goal . If they successfully move the ball down the entire field and cross the opposing goal line they will receive 6 points . At this time they have the option of kicking a Point After Touchdown ( PAT ) for 1 extra point for a total of 7 , or they can attempt a run or pass play for 2 extra points for a total of 8 . They will then have another kick off with the scoring team kicking to the previous defense team . If at any time during their drive they fail to make the 10 yard " 1st down " the defense will receive the ball at the current place and they will become offense . They also have the option of punting the ball ( kicking it ) if they feel they will not reach a 1st Down . There are 4 Quarters to a game each lasting 15 minutes . At the end of the 2nd Quarter ( Half time ) the game stops for a break . At the end of the break , no matter where the ball was , or who had possession of it at the end of the 1st Half , the team that received the ball at the beginning of the game will kick off to the team that kicked off at the beginning of the game . I will not get into penalties or any of the minor rules as most of those can be picked up by watching , and I am not sure I adhered to the " ELI5 " mantra , but that \'s the best I can do . If you have any questions feel free to respond and I \'ll answer as best I can .', "Here 's a wonderful graphic that explains a lot ! URL_0", 'Basically two teams take turns trying to get to the end zone . You have 4 chances to move 10 yards closer or you forfeit possession . These are called downs . If you move the ball 10 yards , you start with a fresh 1st down . Teams usually punt(kick ) the ball to the defense on 4th down for a better defensive position . If you get the ball into the end zone you get 6 points with an attempt at 2 more . If you kick it through the uprights you get 3 . Contrary to popular belief , it is not 22 men piling on a ball carrier . In fact , the cliche " Dog Pile " happens very rarely , if ever . That \'s about as simple as I can make it . It gets pretty complicated when you start learning defensive schemes and playcall though .']
chatgpt_answers:
['American football is a sport played by two teams of eleven players on a rectangular field. Each team tries to move an oval-shaped ball down the field by either throwing it or running with it. The team with the ball is trying to score points by getting the ball into the end zone, which is a special area at the end of the field. The other team is trying to stop them and take control of the ball.

The team with the ball has four tries, or "downs," to move the ball at least ten yards. If they are successful, they get four more downs to try to score. If they are not successful, the other team gets a chance to try to score.

Points can also be scored in other ways, such as by kicking the ball through a set of goalposts or tackling an opposing player in their own end zone.

The team with the most points at the end of the game wins.']

question: Why has n't China started phasing out symbolic writing and started standardizing phonetic ( pinyin 拼音 ) writing ? Would n't standardized pinyin as the primary written communication make it easier for Westerners to learn Chinese and for the Chinese to learn English ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["Part of it is that while there is a unified Chinese * written * language , there are dozens ( maybe hundreds , I do n't know for sure ) of difference * spoken * Chinese languages ( i.e. dialects ) . Pinyin corresponds to Mandarin Chinese ( the official spoken language ) while there are many other dialects ( Cantonese , Shanghainese , Fujianese , etc . ) which will have the same written form as Mandarin , but are spoken completely differently . Having a unified character language makes things easier when communicating between different dialects .", "Yes but changing a few billion people 's written language for the sake of making it easier to learn a different language is n't something the Chinese government seems especially keen on doing .", "There 's quite a lot of writing in the old format -- several millenia of classic literature , history , and philosophy . As long as that writing system is still in common use , all of those books are relatively accessible to the population at large . If you change writing systems , suddenly you have a cultural divide between the present and the past . China does not want a culture divide between the present and the past . Its ability to function as a country is dependent on people perceiving themselves as part of the gigantic country of China . Part of that identity is continuity with the thousands of years of culture . The Chinese government implicitly takes legitimacy by association with the traditions that preceded it ( notwithstanding actual resemblance to those traditions ) . Breaking off from history may lead to a new cultural identity , and potentially one that is fragmented or locally - based rather than nationally unified . That is something the Chinese government wants to avoid ."]
chatgpt_answers:
['Pinyin is actually a standardized system for writing Chinese using the Roman alphabet, and it is widely used in China for teaching Chinese as a second language, transcribing proper nouns and place names, and as a tool for inputting Chinese characters on computers and phones. 
However, Pinyin is not used as the primary written form of Chinese. Chinese characters (also known as Hanzi or Kanji in Japanese) are the primary written form of Chinese and have a long history dating back over 3,000 years. They are still used today because they are an important part of Chinese culture and history, and they are also very efficient for written communication. 
One of the main reasons that Pinyin is not used as the primary written form of Chinese is that it cannot fully represent the sounds and meanings of Chinese words. Chinese characters, on the other hand, can convey the full meaning and pronunciation of a word in a single character. For example, the Chinese character for "water" is 水, which is pronounced "shui" in Mandarin. Pinyin cannot represent the meaning of the character, only the pronunciation. 
Additionally, replacing Chinese characters with Pinyin as the primary written form of Chinese would be a massive undertaking that would involve changing the way that Chinese is taught in schools, updating dictionaries and other reference materials, and potentially requiring people to learn a new writing system. It would also be difficult to determine a standard way to represent the many different regional accents and dialects of Chinese using the Roman alphabet. 
In summary, while Pinyin is a useful tool for learning Chinese and transcribing proper nouns, it is not used as the primary written form of Chinese because it cannot fully represent the sounds and meanings of Chinese words, and replacing Chinese characters with Pinyin would be a major undertaking.']

question: Evolution Please explain to me Evolution , the way I have been brought up I have never learned about it . Thanks . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['Basically it is very Very simple . So simple that we ca n\'t see it and have problems understand it . This is what it is : You have two mice mating . This results in a litter of 3 mice . * Mouse 1 - has a very very very small change in the way its eyes sees light . * Mouse 2 - has a very very very slight change of the structure of the fur . * Mouse 3 - has a very very very slight difference in motorskills in its paws . All these changes are random and it is not really seen . What happens next is that the environment will throw situations at them : It might be a forest with a high thick canopy - suddenly this very slight change in mouse 1 means that it has a very very very small chance of seeing that predator before the others . That very small chance when multiplied with all the mice in that bit of forest will by time have a larger chance to survive to breed themselves , this enhances the trait even more . That is evolution . Survival of the fittest does not mean that everyone else dies of , it means that they have a smaller chance of breeding themselves . This is why it is so problematic with how fast us humans can change environment . The animals living there ( or indeed the plants ) just can not adapt to a rapid changing environment . * * * But what if these three mice lived in the Scottish highlands instead of the dark forest ? Well , that very slight change in the fur might mean that that mouse stays dry and there by keeps it \'s warmth better than the other two . This means a very slight boost in the odds of surviving there - the better eyes means less in that environment and would not give that mouse as much of an edge . Then again , maybe these mice lives in a city , it might be halfway dark , but there are many walls to climb , and perhaps the third mouse is slightly better at that , meaning it can get to places the others have problems with , resulting in finding more food and a higher survival rate . * * * The thing with evolution is that it is not observable in on generation , we might be talking hundreds or even hundreds of thousands of generations for that very very small change to he a real impact on the animal or plant . Our eyes might have stated out as something that noticed the difference between light and dark and that only . Not in itself very useful , but as it got those very small changes that might have added " in between " into the light and dark spectrum and so on . Ah , I hope I make any kind of sense here . My English is failing me . * Edit : [ Here is a search for " Evolution " in ELI5 sorted by " Top " ] ( URL_0 ) - you will find several lovely and better replies than mine there .', 'Organisms reproduce by making slightly inaccurate copies of themselves . Those differences ( mutations ) are often bad but very rarely helpful to survival in a particular environment . Competing in an environment is hard , so all but the best at living there tend to die out ( natural selection ) . As time passes the mutations build up to the point that two populations of organisms isolated from each other will no longer be able to reproduce together ( speciation ) . From looking at all known organisms we can tell that all life on Earth had a common ancestor long ago , and through gradual mutation , isolation , and natural selection grew into the variety we see today ( common descent ) .', "Things that are good at not being dead tend to be the least dead the most . Because of that , the tings that are the best at being not dead do n't die as much as those that are bad at living . In a world where there are limited resources , only a certain amount of things can be not dead at once , so the things that are living need to be really good at not being dead . Because when two animals have sex and make babies , those babies often inherit the skill ( or lack of ) of not being dead , a higher level of skill at living becomes needed to not be dead . Sometimes a baby will get a random bit of genetic stuff that makes them better or worse at being dead , and they can pass it on , accelerating the heightening of the level of skill at living needed to avoid being dead ."]

["Sure! Evolution is the process by which living things change over time. It's kind of like how you grow and change as you get older. But instead of just changing over a few years, evolution happens over many, many years.

All living things have traits, or characteristics, that they can pass down to their babies. For example, some people have brown eyes and some people have blue eyes. If a mom and a dad with brown eyes have a baby, the baby might have brown eyes too. That's because the baby gets some traits from the mom and some traits from the dad.

Sometimes, though, a baby might get a trait that it didn't get from its mom or dad. Maybe the baby will have a new trait that no one in its family has ever had before. This can happen because of something called a mutation, which is a change in the genes that control how a living thing looks and acts. Mutations can be small, like a change in the color of a flower, or big, like a change in the shape of a beak.

Over time, living things with traits that help them survive and have babies will have more babies than living things with traits that don't help them survive. This is because the living things with helpful traits are more likely to survive and pass their traits down to their babies.

So, over many, many years, the traits of a group of living things can change. This is called evolution. Evolution helps living things adapt to their environment and helps them survive. It's a very slow process, but it's an important part of how living things change and grow over time."]

question: Why the Mona Lisa is so famous ? It just seems like some painting to me , why is it such a big deal ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["Well , to start , the Mona Lisa was painted by one of the most iconic figure in the times of the Renaissance which is Leonardo DaVinci . His anatomical studies of humans by examining and dissecting human cadavers and the Phi ratio ( eg . the Vitruvian Man ) has been used in his paintings , accurately representing the human body with near - perfect anatomical accuracy . It also introduced the three - quarter pose portrait layout . Previous paintings looked more stiff while the three - quarter pose used on the Mona Lisa looked more lifelike . Also , prior artworks had the same level of detail of the background and the subject . In the Mona Lisa , the background was more out of focus and the level of detail is significantly lower than the level of detail used on the subject , thus making it look like it was painted in the painter 's POV .", 'One is who painted it . Leonardo Da Vinci is famous for many reasons , both in art and science . It is also a very fine painting in its own right . But beyond a certain level , fame feeds on itself . It is famous because of its fame .', "I once had a nutty art teacher equate it to an early feminist piece . Her justification is as follows : All the portraits at the time were in the most lavish settings in the owners estate , dripping with every piece if jewelry the person owned to demonstrate wealth and power . In portraits , especially those featuring only women , they wore pieces that flaunted their husband 's wealth and affluence . Women were not individuals back then , but part of their husband 's amassed wealth and influence . The Mona Lisa is the antitheses of that trend . It is simply a picture of an independent woman belonging to no man , chained by no title or particular wealth , confined to no palace , and displaying what can be construed as independent thought ( the smirk and intriguing gaze ) . This was absolutely radical given the era . Not sure how common that interpretation is , but it always stuck with me ."]

question: What is minecraft ? * Edit * Thanks for such an overwhelming response . I 'll check it out Explain like I'm five.

Everybody finds something to do in the game that really appeals to them , and since the world in Minecraft is completely random , with completely random events , every single session is different . No two scenarios are exactly the same .", "Minecraft is a game coded entirely in Java made by ' Notch ' . The game is graphically simple purely because that is the way it was intended to be . Whether it be punching the first tree , crafting something new , killing a monster and getting an item from it , finding ore underground . The whole point is to not space the small feeling of success out too much to keep the player hooked . * Graphics : While I understand people \'s issues with the graphics , I also feel that it \'s a contributor to the game \'s success . With modern games , graphics do most of the thinking for you , trying to make it as real as possible . Minecraft does the opposite . Gives a basic world , which you can mold to your will , letting your imagination take over . [ \\[1\\ ] ] ( URL_0 ) [ \\[2\\ ] ] ( URL_2 ) are good examples I feel . When looking at it , you do n\'t see a blocky ass game , you see an epic cathedral that took someone days to build . With a realistic game you \'d poke at the flaws , minecraft graphics are all flaw , so you do n\'t worry about it , you look at what the person was trying to create . All in all , the game is what you make of it . You \'d be surprised how many disbelievers that vehemently mock the game I \'ve turned to loving it just by playing the game around them . You realise that they \'re watching over your shoulder and you just include them little by little until the day when they ask " So ... when you gon na play minecraft next ? " :D']

question: What is happening in our brains when we think ? How does a series of nerve impulses become a complex thought ? And why we can we sort of " feel " our thoughts somewhere in our head instead of , let 's say , our feet ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['Being a cognitive / neuroscience researcher myself , i have to say that this is a thing no one fully understands . The brain and how it deals with sensory input , how it ultimatively makes sense of the world is an insanely complex process . In fact , we do n\'t even fully understand how you can look at an apple and say " that is an apple " , so do n\'t even ask about how we understand abstract and complex topics . Some basic tasks a human is capable of , such as identifying types of fruit really really fast ( within milliseconds ) and really really well ( over 95 % accuracy ) are we now trying to teach computers , as some researchers hope that this will give us some insight on how we do such things with our brain , but only to figure that it is extremely difficult and needs like a shitload of data ( like more data than any human needs or ever gets , we do n\'t have to look at 10\'000 apples until we are able to distinguish it from a banana ) , and only leads to limited results . Moreover , a software that can identify types of fruit can not learn to identify types of animals without having to re - train it completely ... Sometimes researchers go and look what happens inside the brain using imaging technology . But even that only holds limited results . It \'s like clamping some sensors on your computer measuring the electricity that floats trough various parts , and then let the computer do various things to see whether one can identify which parts relate to which tasks - only to see that many parts are involved in many tasks yet we still do n\'t see what they are doing because only knowing that they do something does not tell you what it is , or how the information that is passed between the parts is represented .', 'Unfortunately , despite the efforts of a vast number of research fields , we have no idea . Due to its importance research is ongoing , but nothing resembling a meaningful answer currently exists .', '> And why we can we sort of " feel " our thoughts somewhere in our head instead of , let \'s say , our feet ? Not sure about the title question but I \'d say the answer to this part has something to do with our brain being in our head and not in , let \'s say , our feet']
chatgpt_answers: ['When we think, our brains are processing and organizing information. Our brains are made up of billions of tiny cells called neurons, which communicate with each other through electrical and chemical signals. When we think about something, our neurons send messages back and forth to each other very quickly, forming patterns and connections that help us understand and remember things.\\n\\nAs for why we "feel" our thoughts in our head, it\'s because that\'s where our brain is located. Our brain is the organ that controls all of our thoughts and actions, so it makes sense that we would feel those things happening in our head. Our feet and other parts of our body don\'t play a direct role in thinking and processing information, so we don\'t typically feel those things happening there.']

question: What happens if you break a bone and do n't go to hospital with it . Assuming there is no splitting of the skin . Your wrist for example . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["Is n't this an AskReddit post ? Do you really need to have it explained like you 're five ?", "I met a guy a few years back who had broken his right arm in 2 places , about half way between the wrist and elbow ( the breaks were only 2inches or so apart ) . He did n't go to the hospital -- no insurance , no money , illegal immigrant -- ended up his arm healed after a few months , but his arm was bent way out of shape . Literally , his arm was almost a Z. He had limited usage of his fingers because of the way the tendons were situated afterwards and had a pretty limited range of motion for his wrist . He became predominantly left handed , as would be expected . I will have to try and dig up a picture of it ( if I still have the pic , that is ) . TL;DR , just go to the hospital . It can seriously fuck you up otherwise .", "Think of your bone as a bridge . When you break the bone , it 's like breaking the bridge in the middle . Now the bridge will automatically start adding concrete to the break from either side until it eventually comes back together . If you move the ends of the bridge , there will be concrete moving in every different direction ( secondary bone healing ) . If you aim the two ends of the bridge right at each other , or even put them back together with a cast , when the bridge adds more concrete , it wo n't have to add a lot and can heal quickly ( primary bone healing ) . If you never stop moving the two ends of the bridge , the bridge will never come back together , as shown in the video here with the humerus fracture . The only point of a cast is to stop the two edges of bone from moving . Same with screws and plates ( internal fixation ) . It 's like connecting the bridge edges together with steel beams so that the bridge does not move at all , allowing the concrete to fill in directly with no movement . After the concrete fills in , you can either keep the steel plates or remove then , and you can remove the cast because it 's no longer needed . Bone heals in 4 - 6 weeks when immobilized ."]
chatgpt_answers: ["If you break a bone and don't go to the hospital, it means that the bone is not being treated by a doctor. This can be a problem because the bone may not heal correctly. When a bone is broken, the body tries to fix it by creating new cells to mend the break. These new cells eventually turn into new bone, which helps the broken bone heal. However, if the bone is not properly aligned while it is healing, it may heal in the wrong position. This can cause the bone to be weaker and more prone to breaking again in the future. It can also cause the joint to not work properly, which can make it difficult to use your hand or wrist. If you think you have broken a bone, it's important to see a doctor as soon as possible. The doctor will be able to tell you if you have a broken bone and how to best treat it so that it can heal properly."]

question: What is the little metal piece that coaches press against a boxers cuts ? In numerous fights I have seen trainers or coaches press something against the cuts of the fighter . What is it and what does it do ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['Fighter / cornerman here : That is a knot - knocker . As was said elsewhere , it is used to reduce swelling . It is kept cold , and the combination of cold and pressure can help reduce , or least stall , swelling . Swelling is dangerous because it can reduce vision , and when you can not see , then you can not defend well . A typical cornerman bucket has two sides -- a dry side , and a side filled with ice . The bucket is prepped an hour or so before the fight , and the knot - knocker is placed in the ice to get really cold ( we keep the water bottle on the cold side too ) . The dry side will have vaseline , q - tips , coagulants ( when allowed -- some state athletic commissions do not permit the use of coagulants ) , and random other stuff ( maybe scissors , extra athletic tape , etc ) .', "It 's suppose to reduce swelling . It 's cold and absorbs body heat quickly .", 'Some use blades to release the blood pressure which reduces the swelling .']
chatgpt_answers: ["The little metal piece that coaches press against a boxer's cuts is called a cutman's tool. It is used to close up cuts on a fighter's face so that the fighter can continue to fight. When a boxer gets hit and their skin gets cut, blood can flow out and make it hard for the fighter to see. The cutman's tool is used to help stop the bleeding and close up the cut so that the fighter can continue to fight without having to worry about their vision being impaired."]

question: How can encryption methods be open source ? I was reading about the signal protocol and saw it has a github page . Does n't this mean anyone can figure out how the encryption works and break it ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['It is a generally accepted security precept that " The enemy knows the system . " That is , when you are designing an encryption algorithm ( or any security measure ) that you assume the enemy knows its design . You assume that , eventually , an adversary will get a hold of the algorithm and therefore A ) you can not rely on the secrecy of the algorithm for security ; and B ) your algorithm should be secure despite general awareness of it . The strength of encryption methods lies in the keys ( and , for asymmetric methods , the inherent mathematical difficulty of reversing the encryption process ) . For example , the most secure encryption method , the One Time Pad ( OTP ) has an extremely simplistic algorithm . ALL of the security is invested in how the key is created , used , and kept secret .', "> I was reading about the signal protocol and saw it has a github page . Does n't this mean anyone can figure out how the encryption works and break it ? As a general rule , you should never ever give ANY credence to encryption methods that are not open source and fully examinable by you . NSA and other parties have tried to weaken encryption measures precisely by creating partially closed source encryption methods which then would have weaknesses only they would know about , and only they could exploit . Which , even if you 're totally cool with NSA breaking your encryption , would still mean that there is an exploit that may eventually get out because NSA messes up for example , and some Snowden type leak reveals how to decrypt all your supposedly secure data . Any encryption method consists of essentially two parts : There is method you use . This HAS to be public , everyone HAS to know exactly how it works . Then there is the key . This key is random number sequence , typically it 's about 256 bits long , sometimes even 2048 bits long . That 's computer talk , but basically 256 bits long key means , you choose any number between hundred billion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion , and trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion . Or basically , number that 's maybe 84 or 83 decimals long . The security comes from the fact that you need to know the exact number , every decimal of it , to encrypt or decrypt data . Guessing such a number , if you guessed trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion numbers every single nanosecond , would take roughly ... Well , 31 million years to guess it right ? Trillion trillion trillion trillion guesses every nanosecond is far more than anything we can currently do , and 31 million years is far longer than we can wait to decrypt something . Secure algorithm is such that you do n't have any good shortcuts that are easier for decryption than trying trillion trillion trillion trillion trillion guesses every nanosecond for 31 million years . You do n't know your algorithm is secure if you ca n't see it . A random 84 digit number could be 834,485,888,921,132,283,384,723,847,928,073,987,476,456,352,956,839,445,342,342,475,324,647,232,344,664,756,578,495,4,543,436,234 .", "What needs to be secret is the key ( or set of keys ) , not the way in which the lock is built . If knowing how a lock is made can be enough to access without having the keys , it 's a poor lock , no matter if its inner workings were known by legitimate access to the source code , or by reverse engineering . ( EDIT : typo )"]
chatgpt_answers: ["Encryption is a way to protect information by making it difficult for anyone to read without the right key. When encryption methods are open source, it means that the instructions for how the encryption works are available for anyone to see and use.\\n\\nJust because someone can see how the encryption works, it doesn't mean that they can easily break it. It is still very difficult to break encryption, even if you know how it works. It's kind of like a puzzle that is really hard to solve, even if you know what the final picture is supposed to look like.\\n\\nOpen source encryption methods can be helpful because lots of people can look at the instructions and try to find any mistakes or weaknesses. If they find any, they can suggest ways to fix them, which can make the encryption even stronger."]

These apps might not have the same social features as Venmo.\\n\\nAnother difference is that Venmo is a standalone app, while online banking apps are usually just one part of a larger financial service offered by a bank or other financial institution. This means that you might need to have a separate account with Venmo, while you can usually access your online banking features through the same account you use to manage your other financial accounts.\\n\\nOverall, the choice between using Venmo or an online banking app to transfer money will depend on your specific needs and preferences. If you want a social payments app that's easy to use with friends and family, Venmo might be a good choice. If you're more interested in managing your overall financial accounts, an online banking app might be a better fit."]

question: meaning of alpha , beta , meta can someone please explain what these mean , and if there are any others what they mean . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["Alpha and beta are letters of the Greek alphabet and meta is a prefix in Greek that means ' after ' . But on reddit you would see them in another meaning : alpha - a male that attracts women , leader beta - opposite of alpha meta - something that references itself", 'Alpha and Beta are the first two letters of the Greek alphabet ( roughly corresponding to " A " and " B " ) . They \'re used as designations in mathematics and other disciplines ; also now it is common to hear of a game being " beta - tested " . The first test will have been an alpha test , which wo n\'t have been made publically available whereas a beta - test sometimes is . Meta is a Greek prefix meaning " after " . It means something that " takes a step back " from another thing . So a meta - rule is a rule about rules and people who are " meta " spend their time discussing the things most people just do - discussing the discussion .', "Alpha and Beta are the letter A and B ( why it 's called the alphabet ) . They are often used to mean a version of something that is n't complete ( alpha being an extremely early version of it , before it is near completion ; beta being a version that is either after alpha , often immediately before the final version ) . Meta is unrelated . Meta is more difficult to explain . If you have meta analysis , then it is not direct analysis of a thing , but analysis of some underlying idea of the thing is question or analysis of someones analysis ( like the site [ metacritic ] ( URL_0 ) , which compiles and criticises the critiques for games ) . If somthing in a film is ' meta ' then it often refers to somthing that breaks the forth wall . An actor in a film criticising the acting skills of the actors in a film can be considered meta . A term like metagaming is when you are not actually playing the game , but focusing on something outside the game like statistics rather than what the game developers actually put in the game ."]
chatgpt_answers:
['Alpha, beta, and meta are all terms that can be used in different contexts. Here are some possible meanings:

In science and math, "alpha" is often used as a symbol for a quantity that is being tested or measured. For example, in statistics, "alpha" is a type of error that can occur when you are trying to prove that a certain result is statistically significant.

In finance and economics, "beta" is a measure of the volatility of an investment or asset, compared to the overall market. For example, a stock with a beta of 1.5 is considered more volatile than the overall market, while a stock with a beta of 0.5 is considered less volatile.

In computer science, "meta" refers to information about a program or system itself, rather than the data it is processing. For example, a "meta tag" is a piece of information in the code of a webpage that provides information about the page, such as its title or keywords.

There are many other terms that start with "alpha," "beta," or "meta," and they can have different meanings depending on the context. Some other examples include "alpha testing" (a type of testing that is done early in the development process), "beta testing" (a type of testing that is done later in the development process, with a larger group of people), and "meta-analysis" (a statistical method for combining the results of multiple studies).']

question: what is 4 G , and why is it better than 3 G ? When I visit Orlando or Miami , I get to experience 4G. It drains my battery , but it is fast ! Is it because its 4 G ? Is it faster than WiFi ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["4 G is actually a standard made by the ITU - R outlining requirements for a mobile data system to fulfill in order to be considered 4G. [ Wiki proof ] ( URL_0 ) ( since I 'm too lazy to find where I first read about this [ when I worked for AT & T ] )", '4 G is the big step in the evolution of cell phone technology after 3G. IIRC , T - Mobile started calling their 3 G network " 4 G " after an upgrade made it much faster . Other carriers joined in and eventually the ITU - R said , " That 3 G is pretty advanced . I guess you guys can call it 4G. " The ITU - R had two big goals that were n\'t being met : speed requirements , and a network that routes calls using Internet - based technology . If you \'re on T - Mobile or AT & T , you could also be on HSPA+ , which stands for " High Speed Packet Access " . It \'s basically 3 G but with a better internet connection . This is the network T - Mobile started calling " 4 G " . I suspect it will eventually be demoted to 3.75G. HSPA+ can download 84 [ Mbps ] ( URL_0 ) at its very maximum . Wi - Fi can go up to 150 Mbps , depending on the kind of Wi - Fi you \'re using . LTE and WiMax are capable of going faster than that , up to about 1 Gbps . And , to any Canadians out there , if your phone is " 4 G " it \'s probably using HSPA+ . LTE phones are usually labelled as such . P.s . Corrections are welcome . I \'m not American . * * tl;dr * * see kevtice15 \'s tl;dr Edit : Network speed info', "4 G stands for Fourth Generation . It 's a new standard of wireless communication and it 's faster .
